text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Croatia will start issuing government bonds to its citizens entitled to compensation of property confiscated during the Yugoslav communist regime from January 1, 2000. The bonds will be paid every six months in the next 20 years.

- Croatian kuna has been introduced in Eastern Slavonia, but 600,000 Yugoslav dinars converted into kuna fell short of the planned four million. Local Serbs seem to have boycotted the conversion, exchanging dinars for German marks instead.
-The main point of the agreement struck by the Croatian government, UNHCR and UNTAES is the reciprocal return of Croatian and Serb refugees to Eastern Slavonia and former Serb Krajina, respectively.

- Post-war tensions are running high, and it is not possible to secure one policeman for each Serb returning to Croatia, but we will ensure necessary logistics, says assistant reconstruction minister Stjepan Sterc.
- A new Airbus A320 plane will join the Croatia Airlines fleet in early June.
- Parliament approved a law against money laundering.

- The success of the airport on Brac island, which holds a leading position in charter flights, might encourage other Adriatic islands to follow in its footsteps. Permits for new airports on Hvar, Korcula, Lastovo and Vis are already being prepared.
- The Varazdin over-the-counter market will have electronic trading within a month, says its director Marijan Cingula.

- Cabinet meeting: The seven biggest airports in the country should be 55 percent owned by the state, 20 percent by counties and the remaining 25 percent by towns and municipalities, according to the draft law on airports.
- The IMF is generally satisfied with its findings in Croatia, but objected to increased borrowing and higher salaries at the state electricity board HEP, says central bank
